I also met several of his regular clientele, and we all sat down and discussed startups for a while. Kurt, Dan, I'll see you guys here again soon!   About the beans! I went with @mutdaline and, since it was our first time here, splurged on their Coffee Collective beans for a top notch cuppacino. Philip informed me that Klaus Thompson, world barista campion, runs this micro roastery out of Copenhagen, but I tend to believe that the devil himself roasts these beans. At $12 a cup it's more on par with a good cocktail than a standard espresso, but that's partially the point of this place - you can get coffee on that level! This was top-end beans that we paid good money for and yes, it was worth it! Ma'velous also provides more affordable options when you're not about to spend your weekly bean allotment on one cup, and by the looks of it this will be just as great. The only place that I know of that can match the espresso here is Blue Bottle. Quality wise, Ma'velous is first tier coffee.  Philip, the guy with the mohawk will be back for more soon!  PS: Clearly this is also a great little wine bar, so come on down for a classy alcohol experience too.  PPS: Look up at the ceiling!

V-5d1N-7rrczXEGYXfG4gA.review_text: Best cafe in the area! Friendly staff, really cool atmosphere, and great coffee (and hot chocolate!)  Also a fun spot for after work drinks, they have a pretty good selection of wines, beers, and snacks which are also really reasonable.

zaz_5qYy3DSr-W8312PCiA.review_text: Stumbled upon this place on the walk to work - was surprisingly good. Cool looking inside (plexiglass machine? great!), amazing coffee, great music, friendly staff. Though I must say, it couldn't be a more douchey name....

UxK635aEbTvikox8MqUKvw.review_text: Such a cool spot! Great selection of coffee and beer... Both of which I took advantage of! The barista was friendly and knowledgeable, and the pricing is totally doable for a drink or two! Beers start at 5 dollars and in a city I feel like that is fair for sure.  If I had to find any issue it would just be a lack of food, but drinking my dinner is perfectly okay too!

k_PSkYpsex3vP-f08xfGxg.review_text: Good coffee, great idea to have multiple extraction methods available.  Seems they need extra / more highly trained baristas, as the latte came out looking just a little rushed....foam needed work...  Blue Bottle on Linden is only 4 blocks away, so hopefully they will iron this out soon....  Perfect location.

qUL8F298WoeaJLc61MkhoA.review_text: I met some friends for a leisurely coffee this morning and it was - yes - ma'velous.  I definitely, definitely recommend this spot to coffee aficionados and interested novices (like me).    We tried the slow cupping - a single type of bean prepared 4 ways (siphon, cold brew, and two types of drip).  I have never had the opportunity to taste these side-by-side, and it was remarkable to taste how much of an impact the temperature, brew time, and filter can make.  We sat at the bar to watch the beautiful machinery at work while Phillip Ma and his barista explained every step.  Basically, my friends and I got a half-hour private lesson in coffee (plus a delicious caffeine buzz) for about $6 each.  We also loved the attention to detail in the decor.  The beautiful custom expresso machine, the hand-painted lampshades, the reclaimed light fixtures, the spiffy upholstery - Phillip put a lot of love into this place, and it shows!  Ma'velous is a gem and we hope to come back for many cups to come!

c3X8oIkgv93Q7kRJZ7xmAg.review_text: Update: Rainbow Grocery sells Stumptown Beans and a 12oz bag of Hair Bender is only $12.09  As far as I know this is the only place in SF that serves & sells Stumptown Coffee so I was really looking forward to visiting this place. I was disappointed.  We walked in and the Barista barely acknowledged us, he seemed a little bothered by having to make coffee.  We ordered a Mocha and an Iced Coffee, $10. The iced coffee was served in a mug and was mostly ice. I asked for cream and the guy rolled his eyes and poured milk himself into my coffee.  I asked for cream, not milk, thanks and I'm capable of pouring myself.  The Mocha was just, meh.  Normally if I go someplace and have a bad experience I'll try again, sometimes you just hit a place at a bad time. I'm not giving the benefit of the doubt on this one. If serving coffee to customers is your business you should at least try to be good at it.   I just got home and ordered a bag of Hair Bender from the Stumptown site. They sell the beans at Ma Velous but I decided I'd rather pay for shipping than spend any more money there.

oRWp73EAzos724vOY4qB6Q.review_text: This is a hipster coffee/wine bar.  We came here to check out the kyoto style drip coffee, but ended up watching the owner syphon the coffee instead.  It's pretty interesting how it's done...almost like I'm back in chemistry lab in college!  This is definitely not your average, run-of-the-mill cup of Joe! The hubby gave it thumbs up and as a coffee addict, he's very hard to please.  The wall art are also pretty cool and very Asian-inspired.

n1kdYXByRHKzkg74DQwuCg.review_text: I agree with other reviewers.  Totally hipster in here, and although my sister and I are not (yes I am not in my 20s anymore), the barista made us feel more than welcome on the Sunday afternoon we showed up, just before a San Francisco ballet performance.  Only reason I take a star off my review is that the mocha was NOT the most amazing mocha I've ever had...I guess the fellow customer who was ahead of me in line talked it up too much.

eGttxee8qfvTMypDGksVbA.review_text: If you looking for delicous coffee, try out Mavelous, serving Stumptown coffee, which is the portland version of Blue Bottle.  I walked into Mavelous to try their coffee, when I was surprised to find stumptown coffee, being a northwesterner I couldn't resist, and I was an instant fan when the owner comped me a coffee after I forgot my wallet.   Also late at night it turns into a wine bar, a great place to chill mingle, and have a few glasses of pinot. Very suave.   Mix that with a very cool owner, and mavelous delivers everything you could expect from a hip new coffee/wine bar.

UVdMooUg69A4pR9LqfEZwA.review_text: Amazing coffee. These guys know their stuff. Friendly place, lots of seating. I'm a latte girl, but they do pour overs and have  varieties for every taste.  A busy corner on market street, but worth braving for the coffee. I've never had a bad coffee here.

vguybeVhVDGETEm68XzggQ.review_text: While Ma'velous has been open a year, I unfortunately only noticed this gem a couple months ago.  I love the coffee, the inside seating, and the name (say it out loud, it'll make you smile!)   1) Yes, $4 lattes are expensive, but they are no more expensive than Ritual and Blue Bottle.  Why I will come here instead of those two? Consistency!  The owner has made my latte the five times I've visited - not only have they been identical in taste and flavor, but amazingly delicious every time (better than a Ritual latte; and on par with a well-made Blue Bottle latte). Ma'velous's espresso is great.  Also, he only has whole milk which I think  (in combination with his skills) greatly contribute to a perfectly crafted creamy latte.  Blue bottle is nowhere near this consistent and Ritual is nowhere near this tasty.   2) The music is fantastic - techno-ish? It's steady, fast-paced beat perfect for studying.   3) Owner is incredibly sweet and accommodating!  I didn't realize they don't open until 10 on weekends - we arrived a little after 930 and he opened his doors for us early!  4) There's wine for all y'all on the evenings.  Ma'velous unique and trendy decoration lends itself to a smooth transition from chic coffee bar to chic wine bar.  I have yet to make my way over for an early evening of wine and cheese, but the wine list has some options (not your typical Napa Cab) which definitely caught my eye.   If you are a fan of Ritual or Blue Bottle - make your way over here; Ma'velous competes with them and wins.

OTcKsnEQ1Fm0EJ5YsSSgZw.review_text: We live across the street and it's so nice to see this place open up. They have a wonderful selection of coffee and wine. Philip is very nice and extremely knowledgable. The decor is beautiful and it's just a pleasure to hang out there.   Main downside for me is the cost. Latte's are $4, which I believe is significantly more than either blue bottle or Ritual. A glass of wine and meager cheese plate ran close to $30. I really like this cafe, but I cannot afford to go here every day.  The name is awful, unsearchable on the Internet and needs to be changed, but that doesn't deter from the experience.

iLjMdZi0Tm7DQxX1C1_2dg.review_text: They had me at Stumptown!  Though I've heard nothing but great things about Ma'velous from friends who've had a chance to pop in for a delightful cup of coffee in the morning or a relaxing glass of vino in the evening hours... I just haven't been in a position to dip in and check out Market Street's finest new hole-in-the-wall until very recently. Or course I've had every intention of doing my darndest to spend some time here at some point, but the final motivating factor to break ground was when I learned they serve single drip Stumptown Roasters coffee every morning beginning at 8:00am. Even before tapping a single pinkie toe onto their polished concrete floors, that alone made Ma'velous one of my new favorite coffee shops in town.  Sure there's all sorts of great roasters here in our own backyard like Ritual, Four Barrel, Philz, De la Paz, etc... but Portland's Stumptown can to nose-to-nose with those cats in an old timey, bare-knuckle boxing match any day of the week. If there's one thing the Pacific Northwest does well, it's coffee, and Stumptown is a perfect example of their prowess in the field. If you've yet to try it for yourself, run (don't walk!) to Ma'velous as soon as you encounter a need for caffeine!  Now that I've essentially found my new morning ritual, I'll have to pop in after work to see if their wines bring about a similar giddy, childlike excitement. It's a really, really cute room chock full of whimsy, so I'm guessing this quaint street side cafe will quickly become a new favorite haunt of ol' Ruggeford H. Joesten III. Stay tuned!

mS-4O56dx6wt5fWxbbx-LQ.review_text: PSA: Hipsters of San Francisco, add Mavelous onto your list. Yes it's $4.50 plus tip for a latte but yes it's also Blue Bottle and oh so well made.   The ambiance is hipster-modern and it's tucked right at Civic Center across the street from Twitter so it's somewhat central and easy to access.   And the baristas are quite sassy... In a persnickety kind of way.   Happy drinking, Yelpers!

b9gyrlB-G23rtqTrlB820A.review_text: Nice venue. Right across Twitter. I liked the interior design and the atmosphere of this little coffee shop. However, the coffee was disappointing.. It tasted alright. But from the other photos I saw on Yelp, I expected pretty coffee art on my cappuccino. It wasn't the case. Small cappuccino for $4. It came in a plain white paper cup to go. Didn't even have a cover for the cup... Maybe it will be better if you drink it there instead of having it to go?

2pPNxXnyh6EDUuBJVuoQmA.review_text: This is a really quaint, charming little cafe-slash-wine bar. I originally stopped by hoping for a delicious soy latte, but I spotted the beer and wine list, and decided to have a little drink instead.  The boy working the register and pouring drinks was really friendly and charming, and you know, pretty good-looking, which doesn't hurt, either.   It was pretty crowded for six PM, so I sat in the back by the turtle. Yes, there is a live turtle hanging out near the back door. His name is AJ, and he is absolutely adorable. Go say hi to him and feed him a food pellet or three.

uSCYNal_CJDPGBYUAenyoA.review_text: Ma'velous seems well intentioned and shows some promise, but (and i think they are something like a month old) has some major not A-OK issues going on right now.  They need some time to ripen and take care of problems like...  The overwhelming smell of wood varnish in this WINE BAR!  I'm sure this will dissipate over time, but they could get some air fresheners, or some flowers, or air the place out or something...  And that IT'S FREEZING INSIDE at night.  I came in to meet someone Saturday night and it was extremely cold in the place.    And they don't actually have the food their website promises.  And I don't think they own a cheese/meat slicer!  You didn't need to hire a consulting chef to offer cheese (accompanied by some tasty salumi) unceremoniously HACKED into irregular, awkward strips.   These are all problems of the place being new.  I hope! So maybe in a couple months it will be worth going back, but other things about the place are intentional that I'm not attracted to.    The offers of olives are finicky/over dressed! You're trying really too hard to make olives gourmet.  And if all you want to offer food-wise is cheese, get some that people haven't tried before.  No one needs your paragraph introduction to Mt. Tam.   And if Ma'velous wants to be useful to people on regular wine bar evenings (after it no longer smells overwhelmingly of wood varnish), they need to add bottles to their list in the $25-$29 price range.    Never tried the coffee. Maybe it's incredible-I don't know. But I'm not going back just for that.

q1t5SRqWxp6TMaXu6e18xA.review_text: Ma'velous=Marvellous?   This place is truly a hidden jewel in the Civic Center area. Not only does the place reminds me of an antique shop from the 50's but is renovated and combined with retro cheek contemporary coffee shop. Their coffee is really good. I think the best part is the cocoa extract that they used, Ive tried a lot of coffee but this place is one of my top mocha destination. Well, it better be, not only did i wait for more than 10 minutes for the mocha, but the price is more than $5!(I think, Its been awhile so im not sure exactly the exact price but its more than any other mochas ive got from SF). Nevertheless, it was worth the wait!  Cheers.

bR2feXIaZMk3R_OqCrjpxA.review_text: SF's secret spot for hands down, the best cup of hot chocolate I have ever had in California.  Rich, decadent, TCHO chocolate.  Whole milk.  Coated the cup and the back of my mouth like a proper cup of hot chocolate should do.

sjXDLpvcrMldagWJJDlBTQ.review_text: Wow. I'm super excited to have Ma'velous around.  Stopped by on a Saturday afternoon. It wasn't super busy, so we had some time to chat with the owner, Phillip. He is extremely friendly and knowledgeable about coffee. Definitely impressed. I learned a crazy amount about ph levels, water temperature, extraction rates, and the whole process in general.  And they have Stumptown beans! Yay! If they're brewing hair bender when you go there, just get it. One of my favorite coffees ever. I have been searching forever for a place in SF that has Stumptown. My search can finally end :) Apparently no one else in the city (and Northern Cali) is even allowed to have Stump beans at this point because they are sooooo selective about who uses them.  The coffee itself is delicious. I tried the kyoto cold brew since I had never heard of that before. Perfect on a sunny day! It was super smooth and not acidic in the least. There was none of the grittiness that I normally find in cold brews, yet it still maintained the same depth of flavor. Apparently it takes about 16-17 hours to brew a batch, and it requires an awesome contraption (see pic) that allows the water to drip through about 3 different levels before it reaches the coffee and drips some more ;)  They have siphon, V60, chemex, and french press as well. I'll definitely be back to try some of these. Most of the coffee options will run between $4-6 for a cup. Definitely worth it.

qe9r7hfzHbNm1amyCPqECQ.review_text: Now with Stumptown and more microbrews.  This place just keeps getting better.

F-vwvPdLybo0AFwbhCB2Yw.review_text: Ma'velous is a great and very needed addition to the neighborhood!  Warm, comfortable atmosphere--dark wood and deep colors--and the long narrow space is broken up by head-height partitions to form booths, so you don't feel like you're in a crowd.  Furnished with unique pieces to form an eclectic whole.  Very good wine list, excellent stemware.  Amazing, mindblowing treatment of coffee. You won't believe how good and complex coffee can be until you have coffee here.    The best part: the owners!  Super friendly and knowledgeable about both wine and coffee.  The wine is stored at the proper temperature (unlike other wine bars within a quarter-mile radius--I'm not naming names, but you know who I mean), and the espresso is exactly perfect--if you've ever burned your lips on a Starbucks latte that's cooked to near-boiling, you will appreciate this alternative! And once they've met you, they'll greet you by name when you come in.  I mean, who does that?  And they like to talk to their patrons!  Lunch Geek (down the street on the opposite side, which they opened a few weeks ago) and Ma'velous are making the corner of Polk and Market seem like a neighborhood. And once Twitter moves in, this place will be even more famous.  They serve light food as well--exceptional cheese selection and delicious salume served with McEvoy Ranch olives (yum). This would be a great place to go for a bite and a drink before or after the Symphony or Opera.

bzCcQbknoZ7WQL5KB356Iw.review_text: Very good coffee from some definite coffee snobs (in an okay way- but they do make a person feel guilty for adulterating the coffee with milk.) The prices reflect that they are expensive roasts of coffee, so it couldn't be an everyday thing for me. Similarly nice beer selection.

C-eN-HI_iI3yUwX0c-awZQ.review_text: When people care about their ingredients, it shows.  The milk here is organic and very tasty.  Their choice of bean: superb.  Barista: friendly,  knowledgable, and willing to share the knowledge and his great personality.  You could taste the good vibes in his pour.  I recently had the same roast he used and it was just as delicious as it was in its home (Heart coffee). Nice to have a yummy cup of espresso served without a side of pretentiousness.

GrktSJ7Bv9t37gwDLIlAwg.review_text: The wine list is pretty extensive. There is even a pretty good bottled beer selection, though nothing on tap. I don't even think the wine is on tap. Which is too bad. Though popularly known as a wine bar, I would highly recommend coming for coffee. They have rotating coffees from all over the world. Some third wave coffees from across the country like Chicago's Intelligensia, Oregon's 49th Parallel and Oregon's Stumptown are hard to find a region where we take full pride in our own artisan coffee makers (here's to you blue bottle, four barrel, ritual, de la paz, verve, ecco). They make it 6 different ways: individual v60 dripper, chemex dripper, aeropress, french press, espresso machine, siphon. Most of these methods you can easily do at home.  The downside is that there is no wi-fi and in a part of town that's not quite so pleasant, but I do think it's a great addition to this part of Market Streeet.

UK-nkxH4s9Vb08jdlJ8pKA.review_text: Cozy place. Will definitely visit again.

_HVQorAvXWMwJ0cxwDp7Zg.review_text: I only go with 3 stars for now because I've just had wine. No coffee, no food (yet). Still, I'm glad that Ma'velous is open. The stretch of Market where it's located needs some more businesses just like this to help bring it back.   My bf and I went in one quiet Tues evening for a glass of wine before getting dinner somewhere else. Since it operates mostly as a coffee bar (and it was a little early), we ordered wine at the counter like we would coffee, which felt a little strange here, even though I do the same thing at other places in the city. Maybe it's some operating kinks still being worked out.   The wines were really good though. I can't remember exactly what we had, but they were reasonably priced per glass. I'll be back soon to try the cheese and cracker plates too, and maybe coffee if I go earlier.

I465k_hnNR2M-sDNEwPcQA.review_text: I think this is the best all around coffee bar in San Francisco even though the owner, Phillip Ma, doesn't roast what he serves. He just carries fresh beans from several of the best roasters around, and because he truly loves coffee, he's invested in great equipment and prepares those coffees as well or better than the roasters themselves. Case in point, Phillip prepared for me a better espresso shot of Stumptown Hairbender than they served me in one of their Seattle cafes. But here you also get to taste Stumptown blends and single origins back-to-back with Ecco, Intelligentsia, 49th Parallel and sometimes Tim Wendelboe. Some other paradoxes: this cafe is very pretty but it's modest in size in a so-so part of Market Street near the civic center. Phillip is modest, friendly, approachable, and one of the best baristas around. Located near MUNI and a couple blocks from BART. Oh, and it's a wine bar too. Probably equally as good as his coffee bar.

HKKJJEy2nynvyiVLOG1UqA.review_text: My go to place for coffee in Civic Center. I love that they offer the cortado (in between a macchiato and a latte), they refer to it as the 3oz espresso.   Both the coffee and milk are high quality and the people working there are always super nice.

dmOdiOGjczpaiAaCLUmuog.review_text: Stumbled in here early in the morning while visiting SF & trying to catch the Muni which was out of service...great! Nonetheless, I'm glad I got a chance to sit & enjoy a nice cup of Stumptown coffee (had never tried it). Coffee aroma was nice & smelled delicious. Cheapest cup is $3.  I've been to Intelligensia & Demitasse in LA which are exactly like this place so I knew what to expect.

KDewJBJknfWvQyHHFNbfdg.review_text: One of the only coffee shops below the 49th Parallel & West of 7th Street where the proprietor is behind the coffee bar to craft your cup on the regular. This former turn of the century bar has welcoming 15-20 foot tin-laden ceilings, dim lighting, comfortable booths, and stools in front of the siphon bar, where Stumptown Coffee is served. Once it was considered an odd location but now I'm imagining many twitter employees seeing this as a prime spot across the street. I reroute my morning and nightly commute to stop here. I schedule meetings here because it's that much of a destination. It's Reason Number 11 to live in SF, just behind the burger at Nopa and in front of that view at California & Mason.

95ViFXQELkF-r_vGbyXrsA.review_text: Ah dangit, and here I thought I had already hit all the good coffee places in SF.  WRONG, Jeanne, WRONG.  Missed this one. The coffee is excellent, here.  You can't go wrong.  I love, love, love the decor (chic and classy, but slightly edgy-- ESP with the awesome Eddie Colla mural on the wall?!  I LOVE.) Philip, the owner, is great-- definitely knows what he's talking about.  I highly recommend this place.  :)  Photos and such stuff here: pineapplebread.wordpress… Will definitely be back.

UPP1RCn3J4rtdmzVEMBoCw.review_text: A great little space that deserves all five stars for their wide selection of alc for a very narrow estate in the heart of Market Street.   Books to read, comfortable seats to lounge in and a very warm sun-filled cafe at noon to sip a beer!

4DOFVu9HFx6T5MqCEZFKWw.review_text: This amazing little coffee shop came to the rescue when I was informed that it would take the Honda dealership 6 hours to work on my car! I sat at the bar area near the front of the cafe where there is a lot of light. The place is small, but has a very high ceiling so it still feels very open. I had two different types of pour over coffee and two types of espresso while I was there and all of them were delicious!   The baristas were very friendly and know their coffee! This is an awesome spot to come read by yourself and get some work done, or meet up with a friend or two. The option to get beer and wine is an extra perk of this place. How could you go wrong with awesome coffee AND great beer and wine??

yE7cm9Cyo7YZKrzcP-9wTg.review_text: The owner was very nice and made us a good latte and espresso. Wish they didn't have the same morning pastries that so many coffee houses use. Hard to get to if you are driving. Great decor.

FRi4pcAyEj7xdWmj1PpQXA.review_text: Best iced, fresh brewed coffee I've had in a long time.  Neighborhood is kind of lame, but if you happen to be there, pop in.

sYAuw1PW8YsadyXou4oPIA.review_text: Went here last week after work! Great wine list. Cool guy behind the counter. A hipster chair just for reading. And in a neighborhood that's just looking for love. So nice to have an easy going spot to meet a friend.

QVbD5S-YxKhFCu1SQGd2-A.review_text: Tried the kyoto cold brew, espresso, and the mocha.  - first time ever trying kyoto cold brew. I think the cold brew process was able to bring out certain notes in the coffee that I had not tasted before. My friend said it tasted a bit like tequila lol - the shot of espresso was STRONG. it'll put hair on your chest - mocha was a winner and possibly one of the best I've ever tasted. Rich, chocolatey, and totally worth the longer wait for this drink   sadly the drinks were a little pricier than I'm used to paying for coffee or I would have been a regular customer. Maybe I'll treat myself to a mocha the next time I'm up in the bay.

3O6AQoUkCUORDMA2Z30kBg.review_text: Espresso is perfect. Well balanced and has great aftertaste. I would say its one of the best espressos I've drank in my life

JRkVt9wg3Yf0-BYg_tXs1Q.review_text: YUM! Stopped in for a cup of coffee, stayed for a cupcake...  I love that this place goes beyond the usual corner store coffee shop.  Instead of going in each time and getting the same old  same old, I chat with the (usually) ladies and see what is new.  Yeah for a break in the routine!  Would love to give it five stars, but obviously have a few bugs to work out...supplying everything they have on their menu, getting up to speed on register, etc...  But, can't wait to go back to try the wine...

smKxbOJb9p2SrwSyOFHwvg.review_text: We're spoiled for choice when it comes to coffee on the west coast and this place lives up to that reputation. The coffee is excellent. I've even tried the "Tasting menu" which gives me three varieties of brews (espresso, drip, and a cappuccino). It really opened my eyes to how differently the brews can taste; never mind how wired I was the rest of the day. The tea is also excellent.  All of it is organic and free trade so the prices are more then you'd pay just about anywhere else for the same thing but knowing it's the good stuff helps ease the pain on the pocketbook.    The atmosphere is quaint and a nice break from the workday.  If you're local to the area, definitely check it out.

HAv257_IVJnQT0ZIL8Nn-Q.review_text: OK so the the secret is out. This place has been here for a while and used to be quite calm. However, now with all the new business developments in the area, it has become packed. I can't blame them though. Great coffee from Stumptown (Portland), 49th Parellel (Vancouver), sometimes even Coffee Collective (Denmark) and a few others. Nothing really local to SF I admit but its good to have choices I think and their taste in coffee selection is terrific. Pastries are delicious too. I believe some are sourced from Starter Bakery in Oakland (or so says the boxes). The kouign amann that is here is terrific. It is simple, decidant and in the morning is a huge wake up of sugar and bliss. The place gets crowded in waves in the morning. I even alter my commute to avoid them. No WiFi but sf public WiFi is within reach. But who wants to camp out in such a great place with their eyes glued to a screen. If you come at night there is live music some nights and always "fancy" beer and wine (which you can order all day I seem to see).

g3-4LSFaRu_mDMFg6-SX5w.review_text: Had a great latte today on my first try.  Phillip is obviously serious about coffee -- will have to try some of his other techniques besides espresso (siphon, Chemex, etc.).  Absolutely beautiful decor -- definitely a great night hangout.  Great addition to the area -- still sketchy, but improving.

xfrRKuHXbvz7J_dShdsTHw.review_text: Wow.  Funky without being silly; cool without being austere. Really good and strong espresso.  Philip (owner) is super friendly and helpful. And take some beans home. It will be pricey but better than any pound of coffee you've ever bought!

9IF2ZMnkrZlvxCHcO0h1EQ.review_text: The TCHO mocha is like no other. Hands down the best mocha I've found in the city. At $6.00, it's not an everyday indulgence, but is always a treat when I do decide I need a splurge.

hx0lbwKHg8stt7-18uf26w.review_text: I really like this little place and even though for selfish reasons I would like to keep it a secret, I still feel they deserve that more people will find out about them. The place has a lot of personality, the decor is cool, the ceiling is amazing and the art on the wall makes you think. The tiny room in the back is super charming and perfect for an intimate conversation (you might even be able to still a kiss without anybody else aware of it). It is like being in your living room except there is somebody to serve you coffee or a glass of wine. I have only tried their wine and olives on 3 separate occasions and every time I had a lovely experience.  I hope this place will find its followers. It definitely deserves more attention and more business. Go and check it out!
